\/D:\/repos\/stride-translations\/pt-BR\: Working with scenes has become more flexible.
Working with scenes has become more flexible.
Instead of a single scene, your game can now use a hierarchy of scenes to organize entities into levels, areas or layers, and let teams collaborate on them more efficiently.
Instead of a single scene, your game can now use a hierarchy of scenes to organize entities into levels, areas or layers, and let teams collaborate on them more efficiently.
Game Studio displays child scenes together with their parent.
Game Studio displays child scenes together with their parent.
Individual scenes can be loaded, unload, locked and moved around.
Individual scenes can be loaded, unload, locked and moved around.
When running your game, the <g1>default scene</g1> set in your <g2>game settings</g2> is loaded as the <g3>root scene</g3> and can be used to store persistent entities.
When running your game, the <g1>default scene</g1> set in your <g2>game settings</g2> is loaded as the <g3>root scene</g3> and can be used to store persistent entities.
More scenes can be dynamically loaded and unloaded from scripts and added as <g4>child scenes</g4>.
More scenes can be dynamically loaded and unloaded from scripts and added as <g4>child scenes</g4>.
To get started, take a look at the new built-in <g1>SceneStreamingScript</g1>.
To get started, take a look at the new built-in <g1>SceneStreamingScript</g1>.
It demonstrates background scene loading when passing through trigger volumes.
It demonstrates background scene loading when passing through trigger volumes.
You can now use a scene's <g1>Offset</g1> to move its entities both at design time and runtime.
You can now use a scene's <g1>Offset</g1> to move its entities both at design time and runtime.
We encourage all entities to be managed by a single <g2>entity manager</g2> and rendered by a single <g3>graphics compositor</g3>.
We encourage all entities to be managed by a single <g2>entity manager</g2> and rendered by a single <g3>graphics compositor</g3>.
Enabling VR is now as simple as a single click!
Enabling VR is now as simple as a single click!
Xenko's clustered forward rendering, with its multisample anti-aliasing, makes it ideal for VR.
Xenko's clustered forward rendering, with its multisample anti-aliasing, makes it ideal for VR.
Xenko uses a single API for every device, with native support for Oculus and HTV Vive (more devices coming very soon).
Xenko uses a single API for every device, with native support for Oculus and HTV Vive (more devices coming very soon).
Xenko comes with a VR game sample that shows you how to implement VR gameplay, including environment interaction and teleportation:
Xenko comes with a VR game sample that shows you how to implement VR gameplay, including environment interaction and teleportation:
Save valuable time by visualizing and testing VR directly from the scene editor:
Save valuable time by visualizing and testing VR directly from the scene editor:
Light probes capture the lighting at the position you place them.
Light probes capture the lighting at the position you place them.
They simulate indirect light, the effect of light bouncing off surfaces and illuminating other surfaces.
They simulate indirect light, the effect of light bouncing off surfaces and illuminating other surfaces.
They can make a dramatic difference to the mood and appearance of your scene.
They can make a dramatic difference to the mood and appearance of your scene.
Light probes can be <g1>placed freely</g1> and are processed <g2>per pixel</g2>.
Light probes can be <g1>placed freely</g1> and are processed <g2>per pixel</g2>.
This means you can use them not only on small dynamic objects, but also large or static objects (until we have light maps for those!).
This means you can use them not only on small dynamic objects, but also large or static objects (until we have light maps for those!).
Last but not least, you can now very easily capture a DDS cubemap from current camera position in editor, for use as a diffuse or specular skybox light.
Last but not least, you can now very easily capture a DDS cubemap from current camera position in editor, for use as a diffuse or specular skybox light.
Xenko now supports shadow map-based light shafts for directional lights.
Xenko now supports shadow map-based light shafts for directional lights.
Our implementation uses ray-marching rather than post effects, making the shaft visible and cool-looking even if the light source isn't visible.
Our implementation uses ray-marching rather than post effects, making the shaft visible and cool-looking even if the light source isn't visible.
The graphics compositor is now a separate asset.
The graphics compositor is now a separate asset.
Rendering parameters (such as VR) and post effect parameters can be tweaked in just a few clicks.
Rendering parameters (such as VR) and post effect parameters can be tweaked in just a few clicks.
This is just the first step towards making the graphics compositor easy to customize and extend.
This is just the first step towards making the graphics compositor easy to customize and extend.
Stay tuned for more changes in future releases!
Stay tuned for more changes in future releases!
We now have full support for <g1>Visual Studio 2017</g1>!
We now have full support for <g1>Visual Studio 2017</g1>!
Xenko Visual Studio extension now supports Visual Studio 2017
Xenko Visual Studio extension now supports Visual Studio 2017
Games can use C# 7.0, and our script editor can recognize C# 7.0 and offer C# 7.0 refactoring thanks to Roslyn (you need to make your solution VS2017+ for it to work)
Games can use C# 7.0, and our script editor can recognize C# 7.0 and offer C# 7.0 refactoring thanks to Roslyn (you need to make your solution VS2017+ for it to work)
Our internal <g1>AssemblyProcessor</g1> which perform various operations on generated assemblies can now work with portable PDB (as generated by .NET Standard projects)
Our internal <g1>AssemblyProcessor</g1> which perform various operations on generated assemblies can now work with portable PDB (as generated by .NET Standard projects)
Programmers working with Xenko often go back and forth between Game Studio and Visual Studio.
Programmers working with Xenko often go back and forth between Game Studio and Visual Studio.
To make their lives easier, we made a few key improvements to the Xenko Visual Studio extension:
To make their lives easier, we made a few key improvements to the Xenko Visual Studio extension:
You can now open the current solution in Game Studio directly from Visual Studio.
You can now open the current solution in Game Studio directly from Visual Studio.
Syntax highlighting didn't behave well when switching theme.
Syntax highlighting didn't behave well when switching theme.
Previously, when assets are compiling, MSBuild didn't report any progress until finished.
Previously, when assets are compiling, MSBuild didn't report any progress until finished.
It now displays information, warnings and errors while it compiles.
It now displays information, warnings and errors while it compiles.
Also, our whole build infrastructure and script editor is now based on the latest version of MSBuild 2017 and Roslyn.
Also, our whole build infrastructure and script editor is now based on the latest version of MSBuild 2017 and Roslyn.
Supporting the new VS2017 Project System with .NET Standard is just a few steps away!
Supporting the new VS2017 Project System with .NET Standard is just a few steps away!
In order to provide a better experience for users, we've been working hard on various fronts to make the editor smoother and more responsive.
In order to provide a better experience for users, we've been working hard on various fronts to make the editor smoother and more responsive.
This is still a work in progress and expect regular improvements.
This is still a work in progress and expect regular improvements.
Also, the package size is almost three times smaller, resulting in much faster download and install time.
Also, the package size is almost three times smaller, resulting in much faster download and install time.
Xenko 2.0 supports project upgrades only for projects created with Xenko 1.10 Beta.
Xenko 2.0 supports project upgrades only for projects created with Xenko 1.10 Beta.
If you want to upgrade a project made with an older version, update it to Xenko 1.10 first.
If you want to upgrade a project made with an older version, update it to Xenko 1.10 first.
Xenko 2.0 supports Visual Studio 2015 and Visual Studio 2017 as IDEs.
Xenko 2.0 supports Visual Studio 2015 and Visual Studio 2017 as IDEs.
Visual Studio 2013 and earlier versions are no longer supported.
Visual Studio 2013 and earlier versions are no longer supported.
When upgrading a project from earlier version, in its <g1>.csproj</g1> file, set <g2>ToolsVersion="14.0"</g2> as the minimum required version.
When upgrading a project from earlier version, in its <g1>.csproj</g1> file, set <g2>ToolsVersion="14.0"</g2> as the minimum required version.

Previously, rendering pipeline was customized by magic <g1>IPipelinePlugin</g1> at runtime.

This was very hard to control.

Now, most of the pipeline configuration happens  at design time in the new Graphics Compositor asset.

On Linux, when switching the underlying Graphics Platform, rendering doesn't occur or fail.
